articles.title: Older and younger renters: share your experiences
articles.trailText: We would like to hear from older renters over the age of 61, and aged 28 and younger, about their experiences
articles.summary: The Guardian is seeking UK renter accounts from two groups: over-61s and those aged 28 or younger. “Generation rent” now spans ages as renting grows. The 2021 England and Wales census shows private-renting households more than doubling in two decades to 5m (from 3.9m in 2011 and 1.9m in 2001). Older renters are surging: the National Housing Federation says 55+ PRS households rose 70% between 2010/11 and 2023. The call-out invites experiences, whether renting was expected, affordability, hopes of buying, and rental “horror stories.” Submit via form; terms of service and privacy policy apply.

articles.title: New AI-powered anti-scam tool wins praise from UK fraud minister
articles.trailText: Starling tool can scan images of items and ads on sites such as Facebook Marketplace, eBay, Vinted and Etsy
articles.summary: Starling Bank launched Scam Intelligence, a UK-first AI tool built with Google’s Gemini on Google Cloud, to help shoppers vet marketplace listings (Facebook Marketplace, eBay, Vinted, Etsy) and payment requests. Users upload images, listings or message screenshots; the tool flags signals such as too-low prices, generic/low-quality photos, bank account–seller mismatches, refusal to use platform escrow, and urgency/pressure. Praised by fraud minister Lord Hanson, it lifted payment cancellations 300% in testing and claims 90% image scam-indicator detection. Debuting at a Las Vegas fintech event, it targets prevalent purchase scams (now at a record since 2020). In-app, opt-in, and used most for tickets and trainers.

articles.title: Consumers: tell us how you feel about large quantities of emails from brands
articles.trailText: Whether it’s transactional confirmation messages, special offer alerts, abandoned cart reminders or newsletters, we’d like to hear what people make of the steady influx of emails from brands
articles.summary: Callout seeking consumer views on the surge of brand emails. A single online purchase can trigger a dozen messages: order, processing, courier handover, dispatch, transit and delivery confirmations, plus multiple review prompts. Beyond transactional notices, companies send welcome emails, newsletters, special-offer alerts, abandoned-cart reminders and other unsolicited marketing. The editors ask how you feel about this steady influx, whether you’ve tried to avoid receiving such emails, and if it’s changed your shopping habits. Or do you appreciate frequent updates and tracking? Readers are invited to share experiences, coping tactics, and any impact on purchasing behavior.

articles.title: The best Halloween money-saving tricks, from DIY costumes to cheap treats
articles.trailText: From deals on sweets to ways of getting into the spooky mood cheaply or for free
articles.summary: With sweets rising (Haribo Starmix 22-pack at Tesco £3 vs £2.35 in 2024; chocolate +18.1% y/y), cut costs by bulk-buying individually wrapped treats and checking count/kg: B&M Popping Candy 36/£1; Morrisons Swizzels 16/£1.25 (£1 More Card); Asda Haribo 22/£1.98. DIY costumes/decor from wardrobe/cardboard; Tesco glow sticks 15/£1.50; reuse buys (Cancer Research spider doorstop £6.99) and thrift in November. Host instead of £34-a-head outings: apples 6/99p (Asda) for bobbing; haunt your lounge with free SFX apps. Pumpkins: Sainsbury’s £2 (£1.75 Nectar), Asda £1.88; Tesco munchkins 60p/2 for £1; Aldi 42p; free patches (Orway Porch, Doddington Hall, South Farm). Films cheap via ad tiers £5.99 (Netflix/Disney+), Sky Store sales, Cineworld £5.99, Time Out popup £6.66.

articles.title: Our cars were towed away for repair and are being held to ransom
articles.trailText: They are hostage in a repair shop and won’t be released over a debt that has nothing to do with the vehicles
articles.summary: After Bidfood trucks hit their cars (Jan and Jun), victims BN and NC had vehicles towed by Bidfood’s claims manager VMS Global to Cobra Coachworks. Though repairs were completed and paid for, Cobra withheld both cars—plus about 23 others incl Iceland—citing an unrelated £189,000 arrears dispute with VMS. Owners got no updates, kept paying PCP, and BN received five Ulez PCNs as his car appeared driven across London. VMS only threatened an injunction after press intervention. Bidfood, saying cases weren’t escalated, terminated VMS. Police called it civil. After delays, BN’s car returned with 46 extra miles; NC’s came back after ‘lost keys’.

articles.title: Private rent in Britain now swallows 44% of the average wage
articles.trailText: Monthly cost jumps to record £1,385 outside London, and £2,736 in the capital, with hotspots showing hefty rises
articles.summary: Rightmove Q3 data show Great Britain’s advertised private rents hit records: £1,385 pcm outside London; £2,736 in the capital—the third straight quarterly high. Despite 5% annual pay growth, rent now consumes 44% of the average wage (40% five years ago). Supply is improving but tight: available rentals +9% year on year, still 23% below 2019; new listings just +1%. Hotspots: Fulwood, Preston +32% (£970→£1,284); Keighley and Frome +27%; Newquay +23%; Gainsborough +22%; Burgess Hill, Billericay, Paisley ≥17%. Landlords face higher stamp duty, possible tax changes, and a renters’ rights bill awaiting royal assent; tenant demand has eased amid uncertainty.

articles.title: Girl boss or tradwife? An economist on how a workforce built for men has failed women
articles.trailText: In her new book Having it All, Corinne Low outlines how stubborn expectations around work and home fail to accommodate working women
articles.summary: Wharton economist Corinne Low’s Having It All (UK: Femonomics) blends data and memoir to explain "the squeeze" on working mothers: workplaces built around men plus intensive parenting norms and stagnant male domestic labor. She links women’s workforce entry to 1970s unilateral divorce laws, arguing home production was undervalued and human capital became protection. Low critiques Lean In/#Girlboss for ignoring structures, warns tradwife nostalgia is risky, and notes dating/fertility timelines. Policy fix: paid maternity leave; personal fix: define your "utility function" and negotiate at home. Her arc—Amtrak pumping, Covid squeeze, divorce, move to Philly, au pair, then tenure—shows trade-offs.

articles.title: ‘Crash for cash’: moped riders target your insurance details
articles.trailText: Fraudulent insurance policies are being taken out by scammers using details you do not need to hand over
articles.summary: UK insurers warn of a moped "crash for cash" scam where riders engineer low-speed bumps, then pressure motorists to hand over photos of driving licences or insurance papers. Those details are used to open policies and file bogus claims; IFB logged 1,100 fraudulent motor policies between summer 2024 and March, mainly in London and the Home Counties (Chelmsford, Hertford, Rickmansworth, St Albans). Risk rises in winter. Targets include women alone/with children and older drivers. Guidance: exchange only name, address and registration; refuse document photos; gather plate/dashcam/witness info; alert insurer and police; report via IFB Cheatline; consider Cifas Protective Registration (£30/2 years).

articles.title: Young first-time buyers forced into ‘nature deserts’, UK data shows
articles.trailText: Exclusive: High cost of homes near green spaces may be deepening health inequalities, says wildlife coalition
articles.summary: Young UK first-time buyers are being funnelled into "nature deserts" as cheaper homes cluster where green space is scarce, says Wildlife and Countryside Link (WCL). Its ONS-based 2023 regression finds that for each square metre of green space lost per person, 494 more first-time buyers cluster there. Parks cut anxiety/depression ~20%; living >800m away was linked to worse wellbeing in Covid, deepening inequalities. WCL says the planning and infrastructure bill could worsen loss by allowing building on protected sites and off-site offsets, even in other counties. Charities, including the National Trust, back part-three amendments to guarantee green/blue space, protect existing parks, and require nature in new developments. One-third lack a 15-minute walk; deprived areas are twice as likely to be nature-deprived.

articles.title: ‘My big shop used to cost £100, now it’s £150’: readers recount their shock at supermarket food bills
articles.trailText: We hear your stories of how you balance the family finances, from buying own brands to cutting right back on weekly shop
articles.summary: UK shoppers report steep grocery bills despite easing inflation: Nikki (Aberdeenshire) spends £220+ a week vs £135 pre‑2020, worsened by costly gluten‑free items. Viral Aldi post: £98 for four bags, no booze. ONS: CPI 3.8%; food inflation 4.5% (Aug 5.1%), yet shops ~30% pricier than 2022. Food Foundation: 1 in 7 households with children food‑insecure; 64% cut fruit, 50% veg. Readers switch to own‑label (Heinz beans 4‑pack £3.90 vs £1.60); own‑label share 51.2%, premium ranges +10%+. Anne’s big shop ~£150; coffee £5→£8.35. Price rises: beef mince 500g £3.62→£5.24; Lurpak £3.75→£4.69. IFS: poorer hit hardest; BRC cites £7bn extra taxes; Tesco profits £2.9bn‑£3.1bn. Tactics: swap meats, meal‑plan, chase points.

articles.title: Surge in UK savings lost to investment scams, with fake crypto thought to top the list
articles.trailText: Banking industry data shows £629m was stolen in six months from fraud that included gold, wine and property
articles.summary: UK Finance data show UK consumers lost £629m to fraud in H1 2025, up 3% YoY; investment-scam losses jumped 55% to £97.7m (>£500k/day), with fake crypto leading. Scams often start via social-media ads/deepfake videos (e.g., Martin Lewis), small £250 stakes, spoofed trading dashboards, then 'fees/taxes' blocking withdrawals; one Georgia-based ring stole £9m. Romance-scam losses rose 35%; contactless card fraud up 27%. Stop Scams UK convened banks, telecoms, tech—attended by Andrew Bailey and fraud minister Lord Hanson—urging crypto-sector participation, cross-sector data sharing, and accountability in the government’s fraud strategy. Industry groups demand tougher duties for social platforms/phone firms.

articles.title: Rats! How to banish rodents, bedbugs and other pests from your home
articles.trailText: It’s best to prevent their arrival in the first place – but here’s how to deal with unwelcome visitors if they appear
articles.summary: Stop pests by prevention: seal all entry points (mice squeeze through 6–10mm) with wire wool/metal covers, including around pipes/air bricks. Keep bins, surfaces, cupboards spotless; store food in rodent‑proof containers; fix leaks. Check lofts for rats. For bedbugs, inspect mattress seams, headboards, divans, slats for live bugs, shed skins, black spotting, eggs; check hotels and secondhand furniture; keep luggage away from beds. Renters: notify landlord/council. Humane/DIY: peppermint oil (use cautiously), cinnamon, ultrasonic plugs, humane traps baited with chocolate/peanut butter; don’t move infested beds. Pros: evidence‑led survey, proofing, traps; typical UK rat/mice job ~£180 (2 visits). Bedbugs: avoid OTC sprays/smoke bombs; use chemical+steam or heat >55C; vacuum temporarily.

articles.title: Millions in households in England and Wales are stuck in the red, says charity
articles.trailText: Citizens Advice says 4 million people spending more on essentials than they earn amid ever-increasing bills
articles.summary: Citizens Advice warns 4 million people in England and Wales are in negative budgets—spending more on essentials than they earn—with another 580,000 left with only £50 a month. Using ONS data and client records, it finds private renters and single parents most exposed; half of debt clients are now in the red. Average deficit: £343 in 2024-25, rising to £396 in 2025-26; average household debt £9,963. Energy bills hit £1,755/yr; August food inflation 5.1% (butter, coffee, chocolate, beef up); rents taking larger income shares. CA urges targeted utility bill support, higher Local Housing Allowance, ending the two-child benefit limit, and criticises government inaction and Labour’s delivery.

articles.title: Travelodge guest suffers sleepless night as hotel says it is ‘overbooked’
articles.trailText: Customers told there is no room and sent miles away late at night, or forced to spend the small hours on the street
articles.summary: Travelodge faces complaints of overbooking. A 77-year-old Oxford guest (MAG) prepaid; after a 10pm confirmation call, she arrived to find five others displaced and was sent 21 miles to a service‑station hotel. She incurred £63 extra and was refunded £118 and a voucher. Despite a policy not to relocate lone women, Travelodge later cited a “maintenance issue.” JF in Cardiff was diverted 12 miles after staff said rooms were “trashed,” later rebranded a water leak; he got a refund and voucher. In Brighton, TA spent hours outside during blaring alarms, initially offered £60. Travelodge says overbooking is rare and safety is the priority.

articles.title: The Beijing courier who went viral: how Hu Anyan wrote about delivering parcels – and became a bestseller
articles.trailText: Like so many others, his days have been spent in the gig economy, moving from one precarious job to another, often tied to a gruelling 996 shift pattern. He discusses the harsh realities of modern working life in China, and far beyond
articles.summary: Chinese writer Hu Anyan’s memoir I Deliver Parcels in Beijing, a 2023 bestseller, arrives in English (Allen Lane, 28 Oct). It chronicles his 2018–19 courier stint: 1.6 yuan (≈£0.17) per parcel, a delivery every four minutes, on‑site try‑ons, liability for losses, and time math that made a pee cost 1 yuan and lunch (20 minutes) 10 yuan. Now 47, Hu has held 19 jobs in 20 years—996 retail, 7pm–7am logistics (top 5,000 yuan), bakery apprentice, security guard, designer—reflecting China’s gig precarity and ≈300m migrant workers. A 2020 viral blog launched his literary career. Readers—and state media—embrace its humane critique amid youth joblessness and “lying flat.”

articles.title: Housing market slows amid fears Reeves will increase property taxes
articles.trailText: Post-summer bounce in activity fails to materialise as buyers and sellers, in the south especially, opt to ‘wait and see’
articles.summary: UK housing activity cooled as budget jitters rise over Chancellor Rachel Reeves potentially raising property taxes. Rightmove says September year-on-year new buyer enquiries and new listings fell 5%; the usual post-summer bounce is absent, especially in southern England. Average asking prices for new listings rose 0.3% (£1,165) in October to £371,422, below the 10-year October average (+1.1%). Speculation includes a levy on sales over £500k, curbing CGT relief on primary residences above £1.5m, and a new high-value council tax band. Knight Frank says demand is wavering despite stable mortgage rates; lenders, buyers and sellers are pausing. Treasury touts pro-building reforms and fiscal balance.

articles.title: Suspected scam investment firms ‘exploiting Trustpilot review system’
articles.trailText: Fake reviews, forged certificates and stolen corporate identities being used to lure victims, KwikChex finds
articles.summary: Verification firm KwikChex says scam investment outfits are gaming Trustpilot with coordinated five‑star reviews, forged incorporation certificates, cloned sites and stolen corporate identities, even posing as an SRA‑regulated recovery law firm. Networks boosted linked firms and attacked rivals; red flags included virtual offices. Trustpilot launched probes, removed reviews and a page, added alerts; 7.4% of 2024 reviews were removed (6.1% in 2023), mostly via AI. Crypto‑Benefits247 fell from 4.7 to 2.8 after flags; FCA warning; one victim lost £65k. Oakvests Crypto misused another firm’s CEO video; rating to 3.2. Quantum Recovery Law Group drew an SRA scam alert; profile removed. KwikChex urges dropping “verified” and the “find a company you can trust” slogan.

articles.title: Energy clubs offer chance to reduce electricity bills by up to 30%
articles.trailText: Energy Local, a non-profit, creates a way for customers to team up with green projects to get a better deal
articles.summary: Energy Local, a non-profit, creates cooperative energy clubs that match households’ half-hourly usage with nearby renewables via smart meters and a special tariff, letting members buy local power below standard rates while generators earn above wholesale. Typical savings: 10%-30%. There are 36 clubs nationwide. Examples: Bridport, Dorset (about 60 members using a farmer’s wind turbine, saving 10%-25%); Brixton’s Roupell Park (around 18 homes on community-owned solar). Members switch to a partner supplier, still pay standing charges, and pay higher rates when local output is low, incentivizing load shifting. An online dashboard forecasts local generation. Clubs complement, not replace, the grid, amid rising bills (price cap now £1,755).

articles.title: UK students: have you been targeted by scammers?
articles.trailText: We would like to hear from UK students about their experiences of being targeted by criminals trying to steal their money
articles.summary: NatWest’s survey of 5,000 UK undergraduates reports 57% have been scammed or had near-misses, with young adults losing an average £300 to fraud in the past year; one in four encountered bank-impersonation attempts. The Home Office has launched an awareness campaign. The Guardian is seeking UK students’ first-hand accounts of scam targeting—especially bank impersonation—including what tactics were used, amounts at stake, and outcomes. Submissions will inform coverage on student safety, fraud trends, prevention, and support needs during the academic year.

articles.title: Energy bills likely to rise by 20% in next four years, says Britain’s biggest supplier
articles.trailText: MPs told that even if wholesale prices plummet, consumers face higher bills owing to costs of government policies
articles.summary: Octopus Energy told MPs household bills are on track to rise ~20% over four years even if wholesale electricity halves, driven by escalating non-commodity costs: grid/network upgrades, system operation and low-carbon scheme levies. Director Rachel Fletcher urged delaying non-urgent investments and imposing budgetary controls. E.On UK's CEO said bills would be similar even at zero wholesale. Government rejected this, citing wholesale gas still 75% above pre-2022 and backing clean-energy build-out. Current cap: £1,755 (~£500 above pre-war), with only ~£200 from wholesale; network charges £396 (+£140 in 4 years), policy costs £215 (+£86). Suppliers warned phasing out gas plants won't fix bills without tackling these drivers.

articles.title: Use trials, threaten to cancel: how to get a good deal on UK TV streaming services
articles.trailText: There are many options for getting better prices on Netflix, Amazon Prime, Apple TV+ and Sky’s Now TV
articles.summary: How to cut UK streaming bills: use free trials (Prime 30 days; Apple TV+ and Hayu 7 days; Netflix none), rotate subscriptions, and avoid duplicates. Choose ad tiers (Disney+ £5.99 vs £9.99 ad-free; Netflix with ads £5.99) and skip unneeded 4K/multi-screen. Leverage bundles: Club Lloyds 12-month Disney+ (ads) free, Barclays Apple TV+, O2/EE promos, 3 months Apple TV+ with Apple devices; Prime £8.99/m or £95/y. Share plans: Netflix Premium £18.99 with extra members £4.99/£5.99; Disney+ add-ons £4.99/£5.99; Apple TV+ family sharing. Prefer Now over Sky; grab annual/long deals (Paramount+, Hayu; Now Entertainment £4.99; Now Sports £28). Students: Apple Music + TV+, Prime Student. Start cancellation to trigger 30–50% retention; e.g., Now Sports £34.99→£20. Or pause for iPlayer/Channel 4/ITVX/5.

articles.title: People in the UK: have you been shocked at food prices in the supermarket?
articles.trailText: Have you noticed how much less you’re getting for your money while buying groceries than you did previously?
articles.summary: Guardian callout seeks UK shoppers’ experiences of rising grocery costs, inviting photos of weekly shops showing how little £50–£100 now buys. Official figures cited: food price inflation increased for a fifth consecutive month, from 4.9% in July to 5.1% in August. Readers are asked to share what their weekly shop costs now, which food and drink items have seen the biggest increases, and any products they’ve stopped buying. Submissions can include shopping bag photos and total spend. A web form is provided for contributions, with a help link, and references to the outlet’s terms of service and privacy policy.

articles.title: MG wants us to pay £500-plus to remedy rogue electric car
articles.trailText: After charging, there was a power system malfunction but MG closed the case and insisted a safety check was at our own expense
articles.summary: An MG5 EV allegedly went out of control after motorway charging: it wouldn’t power down, then surged forward when put in reverse, failed to brake, hit the AA van, and spun its wheels. AA deemed it unsafe, transported it, and covered £2,500 repairs. The dealer found no fault and sought £500 for investigation; MG initially closed the case despite the warranty. After press intervention, MG performed further checks using multiple public chargers and a 25-mile test, found no malfunction, and waived fees. With similar incidents reported, the owner lost confidence after six weeks and plans to sell.

articles.title: BA stalls over paying out £220 flight compensation
articles.trailText: First it said it was bad weather so the rules exempted it, then that it was an operational issue
articles.summary: British Airways cancelled a Tui package flight home from Switzerland, rebooking ~40 passengers 36 hours later, then refused the £220 per person compensation due under EU/UK Regulation EC 261/2004, citing adverse weather. Yet its insurer letter gave “operational reasons,” blocking both airline payout and insurance. BA later claimed weather‑displaced crew caused knock‑on disruption, and ignored questions on timings. Bott & Co say such knock‑ons aren’t “extraordinary circumstances,” so compensation is owed. After the case went to ADR body CEDR and the Guardian challenged apparent stalling, BA paid; other affected passengers may still lack redress.

articles.title: Generational shift as millennials make up half of new buy-to-let investors in England and Wales
articles.trailText: Surprise finding by Hamptons shows age group comprises 50% of all new shareholders in firms set up this year
articles.summary: Millennials now comprise 50% of new shareholders in buy-to-let companies in England and Wales, up from 40% five years ago, per Hamptons/Companies House. Despite April’s surcharge rising to 5% (from 3%), landlords bought 11.3% of homes in Q3, near last year’s level. Hamptons expects millennials to form 33,395 BTL companies in 2025, over twice 2020. Investor buying has shifted north: London/SE/SW/E now 34% of purchases (50% in 2016); the North East’s share is 28.4% versus London’s 8%. New-let rents fell 0.3% YoY to £1,398; London −2.7%, inner London −4.6% to £2,766. BTL firms are now the UK’s largest business type; Gen Z incorporations overtook boomers.

articles.title: ‘£850 to skip the queue’: how scammers are exploiting driving test delays
articles.trailText: Criminals claim there are ways to get a licence without exams. Accepting puts you at risk of identity theft and even prison
articles.summary: Scammers are exploiting GB driving-test backlogs (avg 22 weeks; London 24) by selling licences without exams via social media/WhatsApp. They claim DVSA/DVLA insiders will upload fake passes, charging £500-£850 (eg £200 upfront; £740 auto; £850 manual), request provisional-licence screenshots, bank transfers, and personal details. DVLA/DVSA deny involvement, warn documents are counterfeit; possession can mean up to 10 years' jail. DVSA says 668,128 practical tests were booked at end-Sept (579,138 a year earlier). TSB reports losses tied to lesson/test fraud doubled; average loss £244; almost all scams run on social platforms. TikTok banned three accounts; Instagram removed two.

articles.title: What price loyalty? UK supermarket cards rated
articles.trailText: As prices rise, we look at whether schemes such as Tesco’s Clubcard and Sainsbury’s Nectar are a good deal
articles.summary: With grocery inflation high, UK supermarket loyalty cards now feel essential. Mintel says 76% use one; Tesco has 24m Clubcards, Nectar 27m. CMA’s review of 50,000 loyalty offers found 92% genuine savings but urged shoppers to compare. Ratings: Tesco Clubcard 8/10—1pt/£1=1p, 2x partner rewards, 10k weekly Clubcard Prices (claimed £375/yr), strong personalisation; non-members pay more. Sainsbury’s Nectar 8/10—1pt=0.5p, 500+ partners, Nectar Prices + personalised offers claim £450/yr (323+169). Asda Rewards 4/10—app missions build a cashpot; savings delayed. Lidl Plus 7/10—app-only weekly/personalised deals, Coupon Plus, self-scan; digital exclusion. Co-op 5/10—£1 one-off join, members’ prices, two weekly offers. Waitrose 6/10—vouchers, free hot drinks, ‘little treats’ trial. M&S Sparks 4/10—personalised/clothing perks, birthday freebies. Morrisons More 6/10—points (5,000=£5), fewer upfront deals, expiry. Which?: Aldi cheapest; big baskets still cheaper at Asda than Tesco+Clubcard.

articles.title: TikTok influencers fuelling parallel market for unlicensed weight-loss drug
articles.trailText: Guardian finds a thriving trade on Telegram for retatrutide, which is still in clinical trials and illegal to sell
articles.summary: Guardian probe finds TikTok influencers and Telegram sellers driving a UK parallel market for retatrutide, Eli Lilly’s unapproved phase‑3 “triple G” weight‑loss shot targeting GLP‑1, GIP, glucagon; early trials show up to 25% loss. Influencers (Jon Kluth, @MappyMyGains, @clairejoy86) promote “reta,” share codes, push DMs; Telegram channels (to 9,000 members) post before/after pics, injection guides, then route buyers to WhatsApp, promising 24–48‑hour delivery. Offers: powder vials or prefilled pens (~£160/20mg). Sales are illegal under Human Medicines Regulations 2012; some label it “research chemical.” TikTok says it removed content; Telegram cites moderation. Clinicians warn of counterfeits, contamination, misdosing; Mounjaro price rises seen as driver. Lilly: not approved anywhere; sales risky.

articles.title: David Lammy rules out charging workers for employment tribunal claims
articles.trailText: Justice secretary says right to challenge unfair work behaviour is core to Labour’s work plan after union backlash
articles.summary: Justice secretary and deputy PM David Lammy ruled out reintroducing fees for employment tribunal claims after union backlash to a floated plan in spending-review talks, calling free access vital to Labour’s ‘make work pay’ agenda. Fees were imposed in 2013 by the Tory–Lib Dem coalition and struck down in 2017 by the Supreme Court after a Unison case. TUC’s Paul Nowak welcomed the decision. Conservatives under Rishi Sunak had proposed a £55 fee. With a 45,000-case backlog and judge shortages, the MoJ is hiring 36 tribunal judges this year and 50 next year. Labour’s employment bill may raise case volumes; business groups warn of costs.

articles.title: People in the UK: tell us how much money you have managed to save
articles.trailText: We’d like to hear from people in Britain how much they have in savings, and to what extent this money, or lack thereof, has been shaping their plans and lifestyles
articles.summary: Callout: UK readers asked to share how much they’ve saved and how savings affect plans. After a record savings rate in the 2020 lockdown, high rates and the cost of living crisis have pushed many to dip into reserves; unauthorised Lifetime ISA withdrawals rose 139% from 2020/21 to 2023/24. Finder: average savings £16,067 in 2025, but 39% have ≤£1,000, 23% ≤£200, and 16%—about 8.4m adults—have none; among millennials and Gen X, 18% have none. Questions: Is your emergency fund adequate? Have you paused contributions, withdrawn to cover bills, relied on debt, or prioritised saving over non-essentials? Describe how your savings, or lack of them, shape lifestyle and plans.

articles.title: Ovo pricing change could double charging costs for some EV owners
articles.trailText: Customers on Charge Anytime deal who drive fewer than 700 miles a month say they will be left with higher bills
articles.summary: From 4 Nov, Ovo will end its 7p/kWh any-time Charge Anytime tariff, raising ad-hoc charging to 14p/kWh unless EV drivers take a new monthly bundle (from £27.50 for ~700 miles) that also includes a ~600-mile public-charging voucher. Allowances don’t roll over and vouchers aren’t accepted by all networks. Low-mileage users (<700 miles/month) expect higher bills; comparisons are harder because bundles are priced by miles, not kWh. Competing suppliers offer <9p/kWh off-peak night rates. Eligibility still requires an Ovo supply, smart meter and compatible charger. Consumer groups warn of deterrence to EV adoption. Ovo, serving 4m homes, denies financial motives despite Ofgem resilience shortfall; it pitches simplicity and waives exit fees.

articles.title: Junior Isas: how to turn £50 a month into £18,000 for your child at age 18
articles.trailText: Learn the rules, compare accounts and save steadily – five ways to make saving more efficient (and often more lucrative) for your offspring
articles.summary: A UK Junior Isa (Jisa) is a tax-free account for children with a £9,000 yearly cap; funds are locked until 18. A child can hold one cash and one stocks & shares Jisa; CTFs must be transferred. Anyone can contribute; saving outside a Jisa triggers the £100 parental-interest tax rule. Shop around on cash rates (Coventry BS currently leads) and switch if cut. Despite 42% of 2022-23 inflows going to cash, investing typically wins: over 10 years £1,000 in a global tracker grew to £3,284 vs £1,141 in cash (ex-fees). Multi-asset funds can smooth volatility; cash risks inflation erosion. At 16 teens can manage; at 18 they control or transfer to an adult Isa. Save £50/month at 5% ≈ £18,050; maxing £9k/year ≈ £265,851.

articles.title: UK house price growth slows as buyers show caution before budget
articles.trailText: Cost of a typical home fell £794 to £298,184 in September after 0.2% monthly rise in August, says Halifax
articles.summary: Halifax said UK house prices rose 1.3% y/y in September, the weakest since Apr 2024 and below a Reuters forecast of 2.2%. Prices fell 0.3% m/m (-£794) to £298,184, reversing August’s 0.2% rise. Average first-time buyer homes cost £236,811, up 1.7% y/y. Halifax cites easing mortgage rates and wage growth but lingering uncertainty. Buyers appear cautious ahead of Rachel Reeves’s 26 Nov budget, with a mooted stamp duty replacement for sales over £500k. BoE held rates at 4%; inflation 3.8% in Aug. Nationwide reported +0.5% m/m. Taylor Wimpey and Foxtons flag steady momentum but softer confidence.

articles.title: Barclays sent me on wild goose chase trying to close sick mum’s account
articles.trailText: She is from mainland Europe and I have to shut her UK banking now she is in a care home abroad
articles.summary: A UK-based daughter tried to close her dementia-stricken mother’s Barclays account after moving her back to mainland Europe and being appointed legal guardian by a foreign court. Barclays issued shifting demands—original order, £650 translation, then £150 certified translation plus apostille—followed by confusion over whether to apostille the original or the translation, prompting costly travel and tears in-branch. After Guardian intervention, Barclays provided clear instructions, agreed to close the account, and paid £150 goodwill, apologising. The article highlights poor processes for foreign guardianship. A parallel case: Halifax wrongly demanded an Alzheimer’s patient’s signature to remove him from a joint account; it relented and paid £350 to LC from Oxfordshire.

articles.title: Holiday horrors: Airbnb and Booking.com users battle for refunds as stays go wrong
articles.trailText: In a Consumer Champions special, Anna Tims tackles online rental disasters, from a tree collapsing on to a cottage to being trapped in a flat
articles.summary: Guardian Consumer Champions details refund battles with Airbnb and Booking.com. In Provence, a 100-year-old oak crushed an Airbnb cottage and hire car; after 10 weeks of AI auto-replies, Airbnb said refunds were the host’s call; the £931 guests got a full refund plus £500 voucher only after inquiries; the host cited €5,000 repairs. Booking.com cases: Barcelona guests trapped by a failed door lock lost most of a day; a €250 deposit was withheld and a €446 refund refused. A London renter found an empty key safe, spent £123 on a hotel. Refunds came only after Guardian intervention. Which? says Booking.com’s “relevant” review default hides recent scam warnings; Booking.com says users can sort reviews and it relies on hosts. Contracts bind guests to hosts, complicating redress; Martyn James urges regulation. UK DMCC Act 2024 requires “professional diligence” and toughens CMA penalties.

articles.title: Water bills: millions of households in England could face even bigger rises
articles.trailText: CMA poised to give verdict after appeal by five firms for permission to increase bills higher than allowed by Ofwat
articles.summary: Millions of households in England may face larger water-bill increases as the CMA readies provisional rulings on appeals by Anglian, Northumbrian, Southern, Wessex and South East (14.7m customers) to exceed Ofwat's December settlement, which already lifts average bills 36% to £597 by 2030. S&P says firms seek up to £2bn extra capex atop £104bn. Analysts see CMA boosting allowances, notably for Southern, South East and Wessex, citing higher cost-of-equity benchmarks than Ofwat's. Thames Water paused its appeal amid restructuring but could resume. Decisions due early October pose political risks for new environment secretary Emma Reynolds as ministers eye replacing Ofwat and sewage fixes may take 15 years.

articles.title: UK ministers aim to speed up homebuying by four weeks
articles.trailText: Proposed government overhaul of house purchase process looks at shifting some costs from buyers to sellers
articles.summary: UK ministers unveiled proposals to cut homebuying timelines by four weeks by shifting some upfront costs/information duties from buyers to sellers and estate agents. Sellers would be compelled to supply key data (property condition, leasehold charges) before listing, with MHCLG estimating first-time buyers save £710 on average. A UK-wide consultation, launched under Angela Rayner and now led by housing secretary Steve Reed, also explores optional binding buyer-seller contracts to halve fall-throughs. Government offered no plan to stop sellers passing costs into prices. Measures must navigate differing regimes: England/Wales lack mandatory surveys; Scotland requires a home report and faster binding offers.

articles.title: Cut your energy bills by a third? No, these ‘energy-saving plugs’ will cause nothing but hassle
articles.trailText: The plastic ‘eco-plugs sold via social media or cold calls either never arrive or have no benefits when they do. And they can be dangerous
articles.summary: UK consumers are being targeted with energy-saving plugs, eco-plus boxes and voltage regulators sold via social media or cold calls, promising 30%+ bill cuts. Ocean Finance’s Siobhan Blagbrough warns they either never arrive or are unsafe: poor soldering, excessive lead, short/snapping pins, overheating and fire risks, fail basic UK safety standards, and they often harvest card data. Prices can be under £10, yet some victims pay hundreds; listings persist despite Which? takedowns and fake Trustpilot/expert endorsements. Red flags include Ofgem impostors and rebate texts. Report ads to platforms/trading standards; use proven measures: insulation, boiler tweaks, smart thermostats.

articles.title: ‘Sweat equity’: homebuyers turn builders for £10k off their mortgage
articles.trailText: In exchange for 500 hours of work, the schemes can provide more than just a route to home ownership
articles.summary: An Ince, Wigan “sweat equity” pilot by housing association Prima Group and charity HPBC traded 500 hours' work for a £10,000 mortgage deposit boost. The 27-home scheme converted a church into 13 flats (£125k+) and built 14 three-bed houses (£190k-£197.5k). Used mainly via shared ownership (10%-75% stakes, rent on remainder), about 13 families qualified; friends/family could contribute hours. Tasks ranged from labouring to admin/marketing/IT; one couple completed 250 hours for £5k. Several mortgage lenders initially refused to lend; names undisclosed. Prima urges lenders/government to recognise sweat equity; model has UK precedent (Toxteth 2019) and long US history; no repeat planned yet.

articles.title: Tell us: how have price rises affected your spending habits?
articles.trailText: We would like to hear how price rises have affected your spending habits
articles.summary: The Guardian invites readers to share how rising prices are reshaping day-to-day spending. With small luxuries—from meals at restaurant chains or pubs to takeaway coffees and supermarket treats—now prompting second thoughts, the paper asks whether you’ve cut back or stopped such purchases. The focus is on everyday discretionary spending. Citing Gaby Hinsliff’s line that “ordinary things increasingly feel to ordinary people like guilty extravagances,” the callout seeks firsthand examples of what you’ve foregone and why. Submissions are via an online form; assistance link provided for form issues, alongside links to terms of service and privacy policy.

articles.title: ‘Motherhood penalty’ costs women an average £65,618 in pay by time first child turns five
articles.trailText: Women’s average monthly earnings fall by 42% compared with one year before birth, ONS study finds
articles.summary: Mothers in England lose an average £65,618 in pay within five years of a first birth, as monthly earnings fall 42% (£1,051), ONS analysis of 2014-22 data shows. Additional losses average £26,317 after a second child and £32,456 after a third. Campaigners call the hit "catastrophic," citing low uptake of 2014 shared parental leave. Current rules: maternity pay 90% for six weeks, then £187.18/week or 90% for 33 weeks; paternity two weeks on the lower of £187.18/week or 90%. Government reviewing leave, expanding flexible working and childcare (30 free hours from 9 months), though nurseries face shortages and higher fees.

articles.title: No-star review for a request for feedback | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Not happy ATM | Edward Thomas | Electronic ID | Trump and Blair | Days of thunder
articles.summary: Guardian Brief letters roundup: readers skewer incessant post-purchase feedback, mocking NatWest’s email asking for a recommendation of its Didsbury Wilmslow Road cash-deposit machine. A rail-literature nod champions Edward Thomas’s 1914 poem Adlestrop—its closing “all the birds / Of Oxfordshire and Gloucestershire” evoking the engine’s stir. Another lampoons planned compulsory electronic ID as a repository for crime “penalty points.” On geopolitics, primary-school peer mediators could teach Trump and Tony Blair conflict resolution; Trump’s “three or four days” ultimatum to Hamas is contrasted with his leniency toward Putin. Ends with a call for reader letters.

articles.title: Labour considering charging workers for employment tribunal claims, sources say
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Reintroducing tribunal fees would be ‘a gift for bad bosses’, says TUC chief Paul Nowak
articles.summary: Labour is weighing reintroducing employment tribunal fees, with a Sunak-era £55 charge back on the table, sources say. Floated in Rachel Reeves’s June spending review to plug MoJ gaps and ease backlogs, it could raise c£1.7m against £80m annual costs. David Lammy is reviewing; no decision yet. Unions call it a “gift for bad bosses”, noting 2013 fees (ruled unlawful in 2017) cut applications by about two‑thirds and deter low‑paid women. Backlogs are 45,000 single cases and may rise 15% under Labour’s rights bill (day‑one unfair dismissal; six‑month limits). Business groups warn of strain; fee remissions mooted amid a wider £30bn fiscal squeeze.

articles.title: Book on a Tuesday, try for freebies: how to get the best deal on a UK hotel room
articles.trailText: Being flexible about when and how you make a reservation can bring rewards for travellers
articles.summary: Book early for saver rates (Premier Inn from £45 Oct–Jan 2026; Travelodge £35‑or‑less to 25 Jun 2026), or late (Tue often cheapest; after 6pm day‑of if cancellable). Track and rebook with Google Hotels. Train+hotel bundles can beat DIY (Cardiff 2 nights+train £323.13 vs £396.58). Be flexible (Sun–Thu, city Sundays, stay outside centres). Try Plans Change (≥25% off). Stack Amex+Radisson points (£38 vs £110), cashback (TopCashback/Quidco), Nectar–Marriott, Clubcard 2x (Hotels.com/Best Western), voucher codes/Honey. Job/student discounts (Blue Light 5%; UNiDAYS/Totum 12%). Join loyalty schemes/newsletters; book direct; avoid overseas OTAs. Ask for upgrades; watch parking; seek kids‑eat‑free deals.

articles.title: ‘It’s unsustainable’: homes in Great Britain brace for winter with soaring energy debts
articles.trailText: As typical annual dual-fuel charge rises to £1,755, charities warn over record £4.4bn owed to suppliers
articles.summary: Great Britain households face winter with a 2% price-cap rise to £1,755 for a typical dual‑fuel bill, still ~£600 above pre‑Ukraine levels, despite lower wholesale gas, as the cap reflects policy and network costs. Ofgem reports record £4.4bn energy debt in June (+£750m y/y); a £50/year levy is added to bills to cover arrears as suppliers/charities warn of ‘unsustainable’ debt, cold‑home health risks and meter tampering. Arrears without repayment plans hit highs (1.13m electricity; 926k gas). Government/Ofgem weigh a debt‑relief scheme, expand £150 Warm Home Discount (~6m households), while advocates push a social tariff. E.ON says UK lacks targeted protection.

articles.title: Britons preparing to ration energy as Ofgem price cap rises, says charity
articles.trailText: National Energy Action says 58% of households expect to cut heating use as typical annual dual-fuel bill increases to £1,755
articles.summary: UK households plan to cut heating as Ofgem’s cap rose 2% to £1,755, NEA says: 58% expect to ration energy (up 9pp vs January), rising to 64% among those with asthma and 71% with heart conditions. The cap rose despite a 2% wholesale drop due to higher policy costs; Cornwall Insight sees a small dip before about £100/yr is added from April for networks and nuclear. Energy debt hit a record £4.4bn. Ofgem plans a debt-relief scheme alongside the government’s £13.2bn warm homes plan. Ministers will expand the £150 Warm Home Discount to 6m+ families and fund upgrades for up to 5m homes.

articles.title: What is the energy price cap for Great Britain, and can I cut my bill?
articles.trailText: Regulator is to raise the government’s cap on bills on Wednesday – but it is possible to find a better deal
articles.summary: Ofgem’s Q4 price cap for Great Britain rises 1 Oct by £35 to £1,755/yr for a typical dual‑fuel direct‑debit household. Unit rates: electricity 26.35p/kWh (up), gas 6.29p/kWh (down). Standing charges increase to 53.68p/day electricity (~£196/yr) and 34.03p/day gas (~£124/yr); paid regardless of usage. Caps vary by region and payment type; standard credit costs more. Switching can beat the cap: Uswitch lists 24 sub‑cap fixed deals; cheapest saves ~£232/yr. Home Energy’s variable cap‑discount is ~£1,492.30/yr, no exit fees. Cheapest fixed: Outfox Energy £1,523/yr (12 months; £75/exit/fuel); 24‑month £1,525 (£125/exit). Fuse, Sainsbury’s, EDF, So Energy also under cap. Use whole‑market comparison, check exit fees, submit meter readings.

articles.title: The £3m pension pot: is this really how much Gen Z will need to retire comfortably?
articles.trailText: A 25-year-old today who wants to go on an annual holiday and the odd UK weekend break after they stop work at 65 will need to find £1,600 a month to put away, according to one firm’s estimate
articles.summary: Rathbones estimates a 25-year-old Gen Z aiming to retire at 65 and live “comfortably” for 25 years will need a £3.1m pension pot (two-person household: £4.3m), assuming 2% inflation, contributions rising 2% and 5% average annual growth—implying about £1,600/month savings. A “moderate” lifestyle needs £2.2m; “minimum” £947,700. Comfort today means annual overseas holidays, UK weekend breaks, some luxury and eating out. Rules of thumb: by your 30s have 3x salary saved; by your 50s, 6x. Retiring now, a comfortable 25-year pot is £1.4m. Private pensions are essential; state pension alone won’t suffice.

articles.title: Sock it to the shoes: why more offices are going footwear-free
articles.trailText: British companies are trialling no-shoes policies as a way to improve focus, comfort and morale – but not everyone is convinced
articles.summary: UK firms are testing footwear-free offices to curb stress and lift creativity, echoing Silicon Valley trends. helloSKIN’s Natalie James enforces sock-only rules (no bare feet, clean socks; shoes in kitchens, bathrooms, outside) and reports calmer, more focused, creative teams. Tao Climate’s Gary Byrnes backs shoeless work globally. Tech West Midlands CEO Andy Hague, who is neurodiverse, says shoes cut his concentration to 70%. Skeptics: Enterprise Nation’s Aaron Asadi prioritizes tools, cash control and AI ethics. Prof Mustafa Özbilgin warns of gendered and generational fallout. Beyond startups, Delapré Abbey’s Amanda Nicols goes shoe-free—even outdoors. Adoption will be gradual but aligns with wellbeing and neurodiversity goals.

articles.title: Hate your job – but can’t afford to leave? 20 ways to love your work a little more
articles.trailText: In these precarious times, many people hang on to roles they’d rather ditch. So, how to rekindle your passion and purpose? Readers and experts share their best suggestions
articles.summary: With a weakening UK job market, many are job hugging — staying in roles they dislike. Coaches Alice Stapleton, Dina Grishin, Gretchen Spreitzer, Alison Gibbs and Jo Maughan, plus readers, offer 20 ways: reconnect with purpose and beneficiaries; value pay, stability and routine; deepen cross‑team ties; add benign fun; learn outside work (eg Toastmasters); change scenery (Trusted Housesitters); keep gratitude and morning pages journals; tilt toward enjoyable tasks; jobcraft and taskcraft; use strengths tests (Institute on Character); try sideways moves; co‑solve problems; practice kindness; avoid overidentifying with work; and plan an exit via upskilling and networking. Anecdotes include book igloos and internal transfers.

articles.title: Travel FX slow to refund £1,500 after Singapore dollars failed to show
articles.trailText: Currency firm insisted I had to wait for Royal Mail to investigate, forcing me to buy another £1,500 elsewhere
articles.summary: CS (Farnborough) ordered £1,500 of Singapore dollars from Travel FX on 5 July for next‑day Royal Mail delivery; it never arrived. Travel FX refused a refund until Royal Mail completed its own investigation, citing T&Cs that transfer liability to the carrier (five working days to lodge a claim; up to 30 working days to investigate). CS had to buy another £1,500 elsewhere. Consumer lawyer Gary Rycroft says these terms likely breach the Consumer Rights Act 2015, which makes the trader responsible; “currency supply” exemptions don’t cover delivery. After Guardian intervention, Travel FX refunded within three days—74 days after order. Royal Mail gave no comment. Caution urged on home delivery of FX.

articles.title: Staysure wants £30 to amend travel insurance policy that cost £75
articles.trailText: I tried to change medical declaration owing to biopsy, but insurer said it would make two £15 charges
articles.summary: After a biopsy, a Staysure customer (CW, London) tried to update the medical declaration on a £75 annual travel policy. A web popup told them to call, but phone agents said amendments incur a £15 “admin” fee per call—£30 to report biopsy and later results. The Guardian questioned whether this circumvents the 2014 ban on premium-rate helplines and could breach FCA Consumer Duty by creating barriers, especially for vulnerable customers without internet. Staysure said complex changes require phone support and claimed the fee would have been waived, though the caller recalls being told it applied. The FCA warned against unreasonable barriers; the fee was not charged.

articles.title: UK graduates and healthcare workers worst hit as jobs market ‘cools’
articles.trailText: Recruitment report identifies sharp rise in vacancies for warehouse staff and cleaners but large fall in graduate opportunities
articles.summary: UK vacancies dipped to 846,567 in August (-2.1% m/m, -1.3% y/y), with average seekers-per-job rising to 2 (NE 3.36; NI 3.25; West Midlands 3.14; SW 1.3; SE 1.46). Graduate openings fell 8% m/m to 14,162 - over a third y/y - amid hiring freezes; NEETs were 948,000 in Q2. Healthcare (-6.7% in August after >10% July) and teaching (-6.4%) lag; hospitality -6.5%. Warehouse roles are now most advertised; cleaning +6.8%, HR/recruitment +5.1%, retail +3.7%. Salaries rose 8.9% y/y to £42,367 (Scotland +12.15% to £39,127). Time-to-fill lengthened to 37.3 days (IT 50; hospitality 31.9). Pay transparency slipped to 43.9%. Unemployment 4.7%. Market is cooling, not collapsing, amid AI-driven shifts.

articles.title: ‘I can’t meet, I’m on an oil rig’: the signs it might be a romance fraud
articles.trailText: Scams among older people have rocketed, so have the sums being lost. Bottom line: don’t send money to someone you’ve only met online
articles.summary: Romance fraud targeting older Britons is surging: Lloyds reports a 52% year-on-year rise among over-55s. Average loss is £5,219, rising to £8,068 for 75-84s. Scammers often claim to be on overseas oil rigs or military deployments, avoid video calls, profess love quickly, and press for urgent payments via bank transfer or gift cards. Cases include an 80-year-old losing £11,000 to a ‘Freddie’ oil-rig/tax ruse and an 86-year-old sending £2,260 for ‘Stephanie’s’ travel to collect an inheritance. Red flags: inconsistent stories; unusual demographics (only 3.4% of UK offshore workers are women; 96% of UK military are UK-based). Guidance: stay on-platform, consult family/friends, be wary of social/gaming contacts, and never send money to someone met only online.

articles.title: ‘Total panic’: the effect of no-fault evictions on renters in England
articles.trailText: Section 21 evictions enable private landlords to oust tenants, even if they have done nothing wrong
articles.summary: Over 30,000 renters in England have received Section 21 no-fault eviction notices since Labour’s July 2024 pledge to ban them; the bill remains in parliament. Exeter’s Sarah Ladyman, 52, redundant, saw rent proposed £775→£900; a tribunal set £825, yet she was served and fears bailiffs. Leicestershire’s Alice, 33, paying £900, suspects revenge eviction after reporting hazards, taking a pricier let to avoid temporary accommodation for her 12-year-old. Sheffield couple Ryan Bramley and Sophie Hodgkiss got notice after flagging leaks; an Acorn-backed extension plea failed. They blame delays since the Conservatives’ 2019 ban pledge and MPs’ landlord interests.

articles.title: How switching your current account can help to boost your savings
articles.trailText: Offers encouraging people to move can mean ‘free money’ and access to best-paying savings accounts
articles.summary: UK banks are dangling cash and linked high-rate regular savers for current-account switchers via CASS, but terms vary. NatWest: £175 to switch to Select/Reward (Reward costs £2/mth); access to regular saver up to 5.5%. Nationwide: £175 to FlexAccount/FlexDirect; Flex Regular Saver up to 6.5%. Lloyds: £200 for Club Lloyds/Premier (Club Lloyds £5 fee, refunded if £2,000+ paid in); Monthly Saver 6.25%. First Direct: £175 for 1st Account; 7% regular saver (max £300/mth ≈ £136.50 interest). Co-operative: £100 + £25/mth for 3 months if active; 7% saver on £1–£250/mth. Read small print to avoid fees eroding gains.

articles.title: Savvy saver: seven cracking ways to start or build up your savings
articles.trailText: Experts say £2,000 is the magic number to help guard against debt. But even £200 cuts the risk of falling behind on bills
articles.summary: University of Bristol research for the Building Societies Association: £2,000 is a savings turning point—60% lower risk of falling behind on bills; even £200 helps. Seven tactics: 1) Shift surplus from current accounts to higher-interest savings; automate standing orders/sweeps. 2) Roundups (eg NatWest); Monzo 1p challenge builds £667.95 at 3.5%. 3) Regular savers ~6–6.5% (Nationwide Flex Regular Saver 6.5%; Yorkshire BS £50 Regular Saver 6% → £619.50/yr). 4) Prize-linked: NS&I Premium Bonds (3.6% prize fund, £25 min), Coventry Sunny Day Saver (2) 4.3% + draws incl £5k; Chip £75k pot (£10 entries, £100 avg). 5) Help to Save: 50% bonus up to £1,200/4yrs (for UC). 6) ISAs: £20k; Lifetime ISA 25% bonus (≤£1k/yr). 7) Trace cash via My Lost Account/NS&I.

articles.title: More than 150,000 UK graduates have student loan debts of £100,000-plus
articles.trailText: ‘Debt sentences’ rose by a third in six months, finds Royal London after FoI request to Student Loans Company
articles.summary: More than 150,000 UK borrowers owe £100k+, up by a third in six months (113,029 in Jan to 150,450 by end-June), per Royal London FOI to SLC. One owes £298k. Over 2.6m owe £50k+, and 2023 English graduates average £53k. Royal London blames higher fees, living costs and longer repayment terms. Plan 5 (for English starters from Aug 2023) charges 3.2% interest and writes off after 40 years; Plan 2 writes off after 30. New loans repay above £25k income. SLC says exceptional balances reflect policy exceptions; DfE says such debts aren’t typical. Royal London warns debts deter saving and homebuying.

articles.title: Mobile and broadband customers ‘losing out because of murky contract practices’
articles.trailText: Citizens Advice says people who call to negotiate money off can save on average more than £325 a year
articles.summary: Citizens Advice warns 'murky' retention tactics by mobile/broadband firms make renewals costly. Up to 3m customers overpay; those who haggle save £325+ a year. Yet 78% face barriers (over half stuck on hold; 43% maze-like menus). Loyalty penalties cost non-negotiators £28m monthly; almost 1 in 5 never switch. The charity urges providers to auto-offer best tariffs and Ofcom to mandate transparent pricing. Ofcom says its One Touch Switch enabled 1.6m moves in year one (300+ providers) and has curbed mid-contract hikes, after 2023 'greedflation' rises of up to 17.3%. Citizens Advice wants existing customers to receive most competitive renewal prices.

articles.title: ‘Poorly thought out’: expanded England childcare scheme results in higher fees for some families
articles.trailText: Some parents say scheme is a ‘sticking plaster’, with providers incurring losses on every free hour offered
articles.summary: England’s childcare expansion (from 1 Sept) gives many working parents 30 ‘free’ hours weekly from nine months. Some, like a Sheffield father, see ~55% fee cuts. But underfunded rates mean providers incur losses, cap/refuse hours, or raise prices. NDNA reports average 10% fee hikes after the employers’ NI rise; examples: 8% (Sept 2025) and 30% (+£330/month). One Kent family still pays £1,668.92 as only 20 of 30 hours are accepted. Access is tighter: two‑year waitlists, inflexible days; one parent stopped work. Treasury cost forecast £4.1bn by 2027/28 (IFS: +£1bn). Critics call it a ‘sticking plaster’; £100k cap spurs eligibility gaming.

articles.title: I’ve racked up £3,000 in PCNs on the school run despite my blue badge
articles.trailText: Temporary permits for courtesy cars issued by insurer after accident not enough to stop Newham council issuing penalties
articles.summary: Newham council issued 19 PCNs (~£3,000) to a disabled Blue Badge holder for entering a Healthy School Streets zone on the school run. After a crash, their insurer provided three successive courtesy cars; the driver bought temporary courtesy permits for each, but short-notice vehicle swaps caused gaps between renewals. Driving into the zone twice daily, five days a week, triggered weekly PCNs, which continued during appeals. Despite the driver being on record as a Blue Badge permit holder, Newham initially rejected appeals. Following Guardian intervention, the council cancelled all PCNs and pledged to improve courtesy-permit processes.

articles.title: Fix draughts and check your energy tariff: five steps to getting a home ready for winter
articles.trailText: Summer is over but a few simple tests and cleanups can ensure you keep warm as the seasons change
articles.summary: Guide to winter-proofing homes: service boilers annually (£80-£120, Gas Safe), bleed radiators, add reflector panels (£23.90), set thermostats 18-21C; 1C reduction saves ~£60; replace >14-year controls. Draught-proof doors, windows and floors (strips, brush excluders, silicone); save up to £85; cap unused chimneys (~£150) or use inserts (from £19). Energy: Ofgem cap rises 2% in Oct to £1,755; switch from SVT to fixed/tracker via comparison sites; 49-day fee-free window, 14-day cooling off; ~26 fixed deals beat cap, avg £241 saving; Outfox: £1,514/12m, £1,516/24m; 5-day switch. Safety: check hot-water bottles’ date, heaters/blankets (replace ≥10y, £30-£140), sweep chimneys, fit CO/smoke alarms. Outside: fix roofs, clear gutters (£50-£300), secure furniture/fences, shelter tender plants.

articles.title: UK white-collar recruits expected in office more as hybrid working balance shifts
articles.trailText: Job ads analysis finds less flexibility than in post-pandemic period as employers ‘push for more face-to-face time’
articles.summary: Indeed finds UK hybrid white-collar roles tightening: 85% now require at least two office days (77% in 2024; 66% in 2023). Most specify two days (56%); a quarter three (25%); 4% four. Only 15% allow one day (22% in 2024; 34% in 2023; 35% in 2022). Sector averages: accounting 2.4 days; HR/IT infrastructure 2.3; software developers 2.3 (+0.6 vs 2023); lowest are architecture/social sciences 1.6. Regional: NE England 2.7; Wales/SW 2.3; London/Scotland 2.2. Drivers: softer labour market, push for collaboration/culture. Some, like Amazon, mandate five days. ‘Casual dress’ mentions up 10x, but only 3.3% of ads.

articles.title: Energy bills: millions of Britons ‘at risk of overpaying if they fail to read meter’
articles.trailText: Those on standard tariffs who do not have a smart meter should submit meter readings on or around 1 October, says Uswitch
articles.summary: Millions risk higher bills unless they submit meter readings before Ofgem's 1 Oct price-cap rise. Uswitch says 7m+ standard-tariff homes without smart meters should read meters on/around 1 Oct or some September use may be charged at October rates; a week's use could cost about £17 more (due to both higher rates and usage). The cap rises 2% to £1,755 for a typical dual-fuel bill (c.29m homes). 20% have not submitted readings in three months; 6% in a year. Analysts expect another rise within six months. There are 25 sub-cap fixed deals; Outfox Energy's 12-month fix is £1,540 (~£215 below). Correction issued 29 Sep.

articles.title: Candy’s failure to fix safety issue has left me without a tumble dryer
articles.trailText: After initial repair, firm cancelled four appointments following an alert to stop using the machine and unplug it
articles.summary: An 18-month-old Candy tumble dryer was twice flagged unsafe: after a March fix, on 1 August OPSS issued a requirement to warn to stop use and unplug, deeming the repair programme “not satisfactory”. Haier says “variations” can make heat-pump dryers short-circuit and catch fire, even when idle. About 17,000 units across brands including Baumatic, Caple, Haier and Hoover are affected. Candy cancelled four repair appointments, citing no engineers and an unreachable planning team. After Guardian intervention, a technician came; Haier apologises, offers vague timelines; failure to warn risks penalties.

articles.title: Death and taxes – inheritance levy has become an ageist lottery for me | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Robert Thomas responds to an article about family firms that will be hit by changes to the rules for inheritance tax
articles.summary: Letter from Robert Thomas, 83, chairman of Remarkable Pubs, warning Labour’s planned inheritance tax changes for family businesses could saddle his property-based firm with a £6m-plus IHT bill unless he survives until Oct 2032. If he dies earlier, he says sites would have to be sold within six months, causing fire sales that harm investment, growth and jobs. He calls the policy an ageist lottery, quips about staying on life support until the cutoff, and asks Chancellor Rachel Reeves for relief. The note responds to coverage of family firms fearing tax rises that undermine succession planning and business property relief.

articles.title: Number crunching premium bonds | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Tax proves taxing | A canal-boating break | Directionless sprinting | Changes that work | How very Guardian
articles.summary: Letters span finance, health, sport, lifestyle and language. Steve Duffy (Chippenham) argues raising the UK Premium Bonds cap won’t raise money: savers would shift from taxed deposits to untaxed bonds; with a 3.6% prize rate plus loss of 20%-40% tax, the scheme’s effective cost exceeds 4%, above short‑term gilts. Canal‑boaters Ian and Christine Grieve (Llangollen) pause voyages on Gordon Bennett for tumour surgery (nicknamed Donald and JD) until the new year. Graham Whittington notes the directionless‑sprinting irony in a Noah Lyles headline. Michael Fuller touts "get old" as the change that worked. Linda Mockett mocks "jus" for "gravy."

articles.title: ‘Kafkaesque’: teacher in Birmingham fights to clear his name after identity fraud
articles.trailText: Michael Bene is repaying £763 ‘advance’ despite evidence he did not attend face-to-face verification interview
articles.summary: Special needs teacher Michael Bene, 51, Birmingham, fights a fraudulent Universal Credit debt after three 2023 claims were made in his name (West Surrey, Crewe). The Crewe claim paid a £763 advance; he spotted it as a pay-slip deduction in Oct 2024. Despite 80 emails and 150 calls, DWP rejects fraud, citing funds to an account in his name and an alleged ID interview. Bene supplied alibis: in the Scottish Highlands during the Crewe check; at school for another, verified by employer. Locked out by scammer-set security questions, he must appeal at tribunal while repaying. MP Shabana Mahmood intervened; DWP says it is investigating.

articles.title: UK driving instructors shift to automatic cars in industry move from manual
articles.trailText: Electric vehicle take-up is a factor driving change, with manual lessons expected to become ‘clear minority’
articles.summary: AA/BSM data shows a fast shift to automatics: manual instructors fell from 86% (Jan 2022) to 75.3% (early 2025). Among new instructors, 36% teach only automatics; AA’s Mark Born says manuals will be a clear minority within 10 years, making manual lessons pricier as hand‑me‑down manuals sustain demand. Approved instructors are down >6,000 (Apr 2011–Apr 2024). AA forecasts >25% of passes to be automatic in 2025–26 amid EV uptake; licensing may add a fast‑track manual conversion. Automatics need 25–35 hours vs 45 manual but pass less (43% vs 48% in 2022–23). Test waits near the 24‑week cap at ~75% of centres; autos may worsen that bottleneck.

articles.title: Red flags: how to avoid falling victim to a ‘money mule’ scam
articles.trailText: Repercussions of receiving illicit funds, even unwittingly, in your account and passing them on can be long and costly
articles.summary: UK banks warn against “money mule” scams: criminals recruit people—often 18-24s and students—to pass on illicit funds via their accounts. Santander says 31% of confirmed mules on its books are 18-24. Tactics: a “friend” asks to use your account, party pitches easy cash, social posts (#internetmoney), or fake remote jobs. Red flags: anyone seeking access or asking you to move unexplained money. Consequences: account closure, industry database listing, years of credit denial (phone contracts, mortgages), and potential prosecution—up to 14 years—even if unaware, says Revolut. Act: refuse, don’t touch unexpected deposits, contact your bank/support, and report to police. Detection is swift; repercussions last.

articles.title: UK pension savers urged not to withdraw cash due to budget ‘fear and rumour’
articles.trailText: Financial experts express alarm after jump in sums people taking out of retirement pots amid ‘jitters’ about tax
articles.summary: Financial experts warn older savers not to raid pensions on ‘fear and rumour’ amid a surge in withdrawals. FCA data: >£70bn withdrawn in 2024-25, up ~36% from £52bn; £18.3bn taken as tax-free cash, +62% from £11.3bn. Advisers blame jitters over Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s 26 Nov budget and possible cuts to the 25% tax-free lump sum (capped at £268,275; accessible from 55, rising to 57 in Apr 2028). Cost-of-living pressures also cited. From Apr 2027, unspent DC pensions will count for IHT, prompting some wealthy to pre-emptively gift/spend. Experts urge caution and personalised advice to protect long-term retirement plans.

articles.title: Car insurers to pay 270,000 drivers share of £200m compensation
articles.trailText: FCA review finds motorists were short-changed when their vehicle was stolen or written off
articles.summary: UK’s FCA says about 270,000 motorists will share £200m after insurers undervalued stolen/write-off claims, often auto-deducting for assumed pre-existing damage, leaving careful owners short of like-for-like replacements. Following FCA pressure (incl. a June 2023 directive to Direct Line to review five years of claims; Admiral set aside £50m in Aug 2025), firms have overhauled settlement processes. £129m has already reached nearly 150,000 customers; insurers will contact affected policyholders—no action required. Valuation challenges stem from volatile used-car prices, repair delays, and labour shortages. ABI says members have adjusted approaches; FCA’s Sarah Pritchard says fair-value payouts are being restored.

articles.title: Newly retired UK teachers ‘sick with worry’ after delays in pension payments
articles.trailText: Current and retired staff complain about delays, backlogs and poor communication at Teachers’ Pensions
articles.summary: Newly retired UK teachers report missing pension lump sums and first monthly payments due 1 September, citing backlogs and poor communication at Teachers’ Pensions (run by Capita for the DfE). Cases include: £36,000 lump sum and ~£1,000/month unpaid; £65,000 lump sum missing; ~£40,000 lump and £11,000/year pending—leaving some unable to pay mortgages, bills, or credit cards. Trustpilot shows 95% one-star from 700+ reviews. The scheme covers 2.2m members. Capita says four cases now paid, two due within 48 hours; delays linked to transitional protection choices, incomplete applications, and recalculations after the 2015 age-discrimination ruling. Capita loses the contract to Tata Consultancy Services, with handover delayed to summer 2026; DfE says it’s satisfied with handling.

articles.title: UK households put a record £103bn into Isas amid ‘dash for cash’
articles.trailText: Figures show 15m more tax-efficient savings accounts were opened in 2023-24, with more following as fears grew allowance might be cut
articles.summary: UK savers poured a record £103bn into ISAs in 2023-24, opening 15m accounts (up from 12.4m; 13-year high), as higher savings rates and tax shielding boosted appeal, HMRC said. The surge was led by cash ISAs: numbers rose by 2.1m to just under 10m, with deposits up 67% to nearly £70bn. Stocks & shares ISAs rose 283,000 to 4.1m, with £31bn saved. Speculation that chancellor Rachel Reeves would cap cash within the £20,000 allowance (now paused) likely intensified early-2024/25 “cash stuffing”. As rates drift lower, advisers expect waning cash appeal. Lifetime ISAs grew 28% to ~1m accounts, with £2.3bn invested; early withdrawals incurred £102m in penalties (vs £75m), reflecting the 25% charge.
